docs.lead_paragraph: Sierra Health Services Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the Physician Corporation of America under the terms announced in November. Sierra, based in Las Vegas, Nev., agreed then to buy Physician for $11.81 a share in stock, or $453.1 million, or almost triple Physician's closing price yesterday of $4.0625, down 15.625 cents. Sierra shares were unchanged at $26.25. Last month, Sierra said it might end the agreement after Miami-based Physician disclosed wider losses at its workers' compensation insurance unit. Physician has 1.01 million members in its health maintenance organizations in Florida, Texas and Puerto Rico. Sierra has 746,739 members, mainly in Nevada.

headline.main: SIERRA HEALTH AND PHYSICIAN TO GO AHEAD WITH DEAL

docs.abstract: Sierra Health Services Inc will buy Physician Corp of America under terms announced in November 1996; Sierra agreed then to buy Physician for $11.81 a share in stock, or $453.1 million, or almost triple Physician's closing price on March 6 of $4.0625, down 15.625 cents (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Eight people, including five public school teachers, pleaded guilty yesterday to helping a Ridgewood psychologist swindle nearly $3 million from health insurance companies, the State Attorney General's office said. Nine other people were convicted in November in the scheme masterminded by Dr. Carl Lichtman, who has admitted submitting more than 600 fake bills from 1986 to 1995 for therapy sessions that never took place.
docs.abstract: Eight people, including five public school teachers, plead guilty to helping Ridgewood (NJ) psychologist, Dr Carl Lichtman, swindle nearly $3 million from health insurance companies; nine other people were convicted in November in scheme masterminded by Lichtman, who has admitted submitting more than 600 fake bills from 1986 to 1995 for therapy sessions that never took place (S) (New Jersey Daily Briefing)

docs.lead_paragraph: A doctor who gave his patients fuller lips and wrinkle-free skin ended up getting into trouble by making private insurers and the Federal Government pay, claiming he had performed medically necessary procedures instead. Admitting what prosecutors called a ''massive health-insurance fraud,'' the now-retired doctor, Leon Cantor, told a judge in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday that from 1987 to early last year, ''I billed various insurance companies for services I did not render.''

headline.main: Doctor in Insurance Scheme Admits It Was All for Vanity

docs.abstract: Retired Dr Leon Cantor admits in Federal District Court in Brooklyn that he committed what prosecutors call 'massive health-insurance fraud', billing private insurance companies and Medicare for 'services I did not render'; amount of fraudulent billing totaled nearly $1.5 million; prosecutors say that while Cantor claimed his performed medically necessary diagnostic procedures, all he really did, in many cases, was inject patients with collagen to smooth out wrinkles and puff up lips; Cantor practiced in Fresh Meadows, Queens, and Manhasset, LI; false billing scheme described (M)
docs.snippet: A doctor who gave his patients fuller lips and wrinkle-free skin ended up getting into trouble by making private insurers and the Federal Government pay, claiming he had performed medically necessary procedures instead.    Admitting what prosecutors...

docs.lead_paragraph: The computerized medical records of millions of Americans are vulnerable to misuse and abuse, but few people recognize the extent of the problem and little is being done to improve the security of these personal files, a National Research Council panel said today. The committee said numerous steps could be taken immediately to increase the privacy and security of electronic patient records. But it said there were few incentives to encourage those practices.

headline.main: Panel Cites Lack of Security on Medical Records

docs.abstract: National Research Council says computerized medical records of millions of Americans are vulnerable to misuse and abuse, but few people recognize extent of problem and little is being done to improve security of these personal files; says numerous steps can be taken to increase privacy and security of electronic patient records, but there are few incentives to encourage those practices; uneasiness over access to medical records has grown as more people receive health care outside of traditional settings of doctors' offices and hospitals, and parts of their records are stored in many places and often shared by many health care providers; Dr Paul D Clayton, council chairman, comments (M)
docs.snippet: The computerized medical records of millions of Americans are vulnerable to misuse and abuse, but few people recognize the extent of the problem and little is being done to improve the security of these personal files, a National Research Council...

docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty people died at Beth Israel Medical Center from Nov. 1 to Nov. 11, 1995. Each death was a personal loss, but together the cases offer a glimpse of the complicated decisions that arise when death nears and the aversion people have to talking about such matters in advance. Martin Isaacs was typical of many people who died in this period: he was older, he had been sick for some time he had never spoken to his family or doctor about ''end of life'' care. Some families and doctors of those who had died were willing to talk but not to be identified. In other cases only the hospital records were available. Some deaths were swift, others slow. Some involved difficult decisions; others offered almost no choices to families or doctors and nurses. They are presented in the order they occurred. Nov. 1, 4:20 P.M. A Joint Decision At 4:20 P.M., a 42-year-old man with AIDS died after a severe case of pneumonia. He had been in the hospital for two and a half months, since Aug. 17, when his companion brought him in, weak and fatigued.

headline.main: Chronicling the End for 20: Hard Choices Are Harder When Wishes Go Unsaid

docs.abstract: Twenty people died at Beth Israel Medical Center from Nov 1 to Nov 11, 1995; each death was personal loss, but together cases offer glimpse of complicated decisions that arise when death nears and aversion people have to talking about such matters in advance; individual cases discussed; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: At 40, the art dealer Pat Hearn is widely respected for her professionalism, her style and her sharp eye for emerging artists. She has given debut shows for such artists as Philip Taaffe, George Condo and Renee Green; she helped found the young dealers' annual gathering, the Gramercy International Contemporary Art Fair, and she has helped pioneer art neighborhoods, from the East Village in the 1980's to her gallery's current home, Chelsea. But now Ms. Hearn will also be known for one of the most moving sights in the art world's recent memory: ''The Emergency Sale to Benefit Pat Hearn.'' Since learning in January that she had liver cancer -- just weeks after her new health insurer refused to pay for tests and told her it would pay little if any of the cost of a catastrophic illness -- hundreds of artists have donated works to her gallery to help pay for her treatment.

headline.main: When Artists and Dealers Get Together to Take Care of One of Their Own

docs.abstract: Hundreds of artists have donated works to dealer Pat Hearn's gallery and other galleries are donating sale proceeds to help pay for her treatment for liver cancer; Hearn's illness focuses attention on problem of health insurance in art world, where self-employment is norm; Oxford Health Plans, her health insurer, reverses stand and agrees to pay for care; photo (M)
docs.snippet: At 40, the art dealer Pat Hearn is widely respected for her professionalism, her style and her sharp eye for emerging artists. She has given debut shows for such artists as Philip Taaffe, George Condo and Renee Green; she helped found the young...

docs.lead_paragraph: MONSTER Living Off the Big Screen By John Gregory Dunne 203 pages. Random House. $21. The screenwriting credit on last year's ''Up Close and Personal'' offered new reason to ask an old Hollywood question: How do not-so-smart movies happen to smart people? Now John Gregory Dunne, who wrote 27 drafts of that glossy star vehicle with his wife, Joan Didion, has the answer: ''Monster,'' a savvy, acidly funny book that is must reading on the subject of consensus Hollywood movie making and why it goes wrong.

headline.main: Playing the Only Game in Tinseltown

docs.abstract: Janet Maslin reviews book Monster: Living Off the Big Screen by John Gregory Dunne (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The former chief financial officer of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield was convicted yesterday of lying to a Senate subcommittee and obstructing its investigation into financial problems at the giant medical insurance company. After an eight-week trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan, a jury found that the former officer, Jerry Weissman, submitted falsified reports to a Senate subcommittee investigating the insurance industry in 1992. The jury also found that Mr. Weissman lied to committee members during public hearings on the industry.

headline.main: Former Officer of Blue Cross Is Guilty of Lying to Panel

docs.abstract: Former chief financial officer of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield Jerry Weissman is convicted in Federal District Court, Manhattan, of lying to Senate subcommittee and obstructing its investigation into financial problems at giant medical insurance company; government contends that Weissman made false reports to hide more than $80 million in losses that company suffered while he was financial officer (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Helping legal immigrants become citizens, establishing drug courts in four counties and providing health care for uninsured children are among the many options state legislators will consider this week as they begin budget negotiations.
docs.abstract: New Jersey legislators to begin budget negotiations this week and several topics of conversation will be helping legal immigrants become citizens, establishing drug courts in four counties and providing health care for uninsured children (New Jersey Daily Briefing) (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A month ago, $5,876 mysteriously disappeared from Bonnie Lester's bank account. Ms. Lester, a longtime social worker who lives in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, was amazed to learn that her employer withdrew the money from her account electronically without notifying her, something it could do because she had signed up for a direct deposit program at work.

headline.main: When Direct Deposit Shifts Into Reverse

docs.abstract: State Sen Franz S Leichter will propose legislation that would require employers in New York State to give 10 days notice before trying to withdraw direct deposit payment from employees' accounts; Bonnie Lester complains that her employer withdrew $5,876 from her direct deposit account after she quit her job (M)
